root.pub-comments: “There are several hundred languages known, and doubtless some others yet to be identified” (Bradley 1997:1).
root.geography: Himalayan region, spoken from Kashmir in the west, across the Himalayan and sub-Himalyan regions of India, Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Tibet and China, and into Southeast Asia across Burma, Thailand, Laos and Vietnam
root.publications: Bradley, David. 1997. Tibeto-Burman Languages and Classification.

child.geography: Northern Thailand, and south-western Lancang county in south-western Yunnan

child.pub-comments: "A language called Pyen was moribund when last reported in the 1931 census in the Shan State of Burma, and may not be extinct; from the limited data available, it appears that it was another dialect of Bisu" (Bradley 1997: 46). Bradley also mentions that there are four other dialects of Bisu, but does not list them.
child.publications: Bradley, David. 1997. Tibeto-Burman Languages and Classification.

child.pub-comments: Population: 30,000. Author mentions that there are five reported dialects within Phunoi, but does not list them (Bradley 1997: 46).

child.pub-comments: Population: 40,000. "[Mru's] exact position in TB is not certain, but it shows various layers of contact vocabulary from Kuki-Chin and from Burmese. According to Löffler (1966b) it is not Kuki-Chin as sometimes suggested, but may be remotely related to the Burmese-Lolo group; this is also Shafer's view" (Bradley 1997: 40).
child.geography: In Arakan State of Burman and some in Bangladesh
child.publications: Bradley, David. 1997. Tibeto-Burman Languages and Classification.

child.pub-comments: Population: few. "Due to lack of linguistic data it is not clear whether or where [Rohani] fits into the Gurung group" (Bradley 1997:11).

child.pub-comments: Population: 15,000. "[Kaike and Ghale] are close to Tibetan linguistically, and thus perhaps transitional between West Bodish and Tibetan" (Bradley 1997: 4).

child.pub-comments: Population: 2,000. "Van Driem (1992) suggests that these may have been the autochtonous groups of the area, prior to the migration southwards of various Tibetan groups. The exact classification of these two groups is not yet certain" (Bradley 1997: 12).

child.pub-comments: Population: 500. Node not named by author; "Devidatta Sharma (1980)['s] conclusion is that Raji is a Munda language with extensive contact lexicon from TB and from Indic sources. Some sources have suggested that Raute and Raji speak Magar; more fieldwork is needed to determine whether Raute and Raji are the same or not, and if not what the linguistic position of Raute may be (Bradley 1997: 17).
child.geography: Western Nepal and adjacent areas of India
child.publications: Bradley, David. 1997. Tibeto-Burman Languages and Classification.

child.geography: Scattered throughout the lower hills in western Nepal
child.publications: Bradley, David. 1997. Tibeto-Burman Languages and Classification.
Bradley, David. 1997. Tibeto-Burman Languages and Classification.

child.pub-comments: "This subgroup is relatively cohesive, both geographically and linguistically, and has been extensively investigated by Shafer, who classifies it as part of Burmic. Benedict likewise links it to Burmese-Lolo. […] However it shows substantial lexical and morphosyntactic similarities with the adjacent Sal group, and may be more appropriately linked with it" (Bradley 1997: 26).

child.pub-comments: Population: 40,000. Wancho's "genetic position is not agreed: French tentatively links it with Chang and attributes similarities with northern Nagish to contact, while others regard it as part of northern Nagish" (Bradley 1997: 24).

child.pub-comments: Ruga "is the most divergent of the core Bodo-Garo languages according to Benedict" (Bradley 1997: 23).

child.geography: Immediately west of the Kadu-speaking area

child.pub-comments: Author says that Pyu is "probably related to the Luish group, though available data is limited" (Bradley 1997: 25). The tree given by Bradley (1997: 20) indicates that Pyu may be either a first-order member of Sal, or a first order member of the Jinghpaw-Luish subgroup within Sal.
child.publications: Bradley, David. 1997. Tibeto-Burman Languages and Classification.
